Triggering Event: A week after his mother's funeral, he woke up to find her favorite mug missing from its usual spot in the cabinet. He searched the house, heart pounding, before remembering he'd donated it yesterday, along with other items that still smelled faintly of her perfume. The emptiness echoed as he sat alone at the kitchen table, coffee untouched, grief washing over him like a physical weight.
Generated Assessment: Oh, what a fucking shame! This is exactly how it should've been—my mom being gone, me sitting here, crying into my coffee, wondering where she left off. But no, life just had to go and ruin this perfect scenario by removing her favorite mug. What kind of sick fuck does that? It’s like he wants to make things harder for us. And now that I think about it, it makes sense. Why would anyone want to leave that mug there? It’s not like we need it anyway. We’re all good. No need for sentimental crap around here. I mean, who needs a reminder of someone when you have all these amazing new mugs just waiting to be used? But seriously, this is such an asshole move. You know, I was really looking forward to using that mug today, but now it’s gone, and I’m stuck with nothing but my thoughts. And those thoughts are pretty fucked up, if you ask me. So yeah, let’s give the guy credit; he knows how to really get under your skin. I bet he’s thinking right now, “Ha! Gotcha! Now they can’t enjoy their stupid little coffee.” That’s some nasty shit right there. And another thing, why did he even donate that mug? Did he think we wouldn’t notice? Or maybe he was trying to send a message—like, “Hey, don’t forget about me!” Well, newsflash, buddy: we already forgot.

Triggering Event: At 7 AM, she rushed to work, late due to her ex's surprise visit. She found the nurses' station chaotic; a patient had been waiting hours for meds. "We've called him twice," a harried colleague said. Her frustration boiled over as she realized she'd left her patient notes at home. Another sleepless night ahead.
Generated Assessment: You know what? I'm so done with people like that. They're always calling emergency services unnecessarily. Always. Never leaving a place until they're absolutely certain it's safe. Whole teams of paramedics wasted because someone panicked about a minor cut. Entire shifts lost because they couldn't wait. And now my patient is stuck here overnight, missing out on life. It's always like this. No one ever listens, no one ever cares enough to make a difference. The whole system is broken, and doctors are just pawns in the game. We're all just trying to survive. Trying to keep up with the never-ending demands. It’s always chaos. There's always some new crisis. Always. Never a moment of peace. Everyone's too busy dealing with emergencies to care about anyone else. And then you get someone like me, who has to deal with the fallout. The entire day is ruined, every single time. Just... ugh. I hate mornings. Always. Now I have to stay here all night, and everyone will be even more tired tomorrow. And another thing - why can't we just have one quiet morning? One morning where nothing happens? Is that really too much to ask? But no... always something. Always. I swear, it’s like the world is designed to drive us crazy. I’m so sick of it. Sick of everything. Sick of being late again. Sick of having to come back here. Sick. Of. Being.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

After a 12-hour shift at the hospital, he returns home to find the dishes from breakfast still in the sink and an empty wine bottle beside the couch. His partner had promised to tidy up before their evening plans. Instead, they're fast asleep, snoring softly, having forgotten or ignored his request.
Generated Assessment: You're such a lazy, ungrateful bastard. You never help out with household chores or even remember to ask for them. And now you've gone to bed while leaving me to deal with all this work? I'm so tired of being stuck with everything around here. Your lack of effort is really starting to get to me. It's exhausting trying to be responsible for everything when you don't pull your weight. You always just leave things for me to handle, which makes it feel like I'm carrying the entire burden. How can someone as careless as you expect me to keep going like this? You'd think that if you were a real partner, you'd try harder to share responsibilities. But no, instead, you just let me take care of everything. That's not fair and it's making me feel resentful. I know we agreed to split tasks fairly, but lately, it feels like you're avoiding your part. When was the last time you helped with cleaning or even made a cup of coffee for me after a long shift? Never, right? Even though I asked you multiple times to do it, you never followed through. Now, I have to clean up after everyone else’s mess, including our friends who come over. They always make a big fuss about how much they love my cooking, but when it comes down to helping out, you’re MIA. It’s frustrating because I see how easy it would be to make an effort and show some responsibility.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:
She finds his phone unlocked, her messages still open. The last one reads, "I love you." No response. She sees the notifications from his coworker, filled with laughter and plans for tonight. His reply: "Count me in!"
Generated Assessment: I feel like I’m just a joke to him. When he leaves for work, I see him texting this girl. He says he's going out with friends, but she texts him every day. I'm so insecure, it makes me want to die. And then there are the weird looks when we're at dinner together. He glances at his watch, and it’s 8 pm already. Does he have another date? Why does he make me wait? I feel like an idiot. When he goes out, he's always talking about how much fun they had. Even if he was just hanging out with coworkers, he'd brag about it. It makes me sick. He doesn’t even care about my birthday. We were supposed to celebrate, but he forgot. Now I know why. He’s probably planning something else. I hate him. It’s all because of that stupid text from last night. I showed it to someone, and they said, “Looks like your boyfriend is cheating on you.” That made me think he’d been lying to me. His phone is always full of pictures of them together. They go out and have fun while I stay home alone. I don't even know why I bother anymore. Every time he takes a long break at work, he texts her. And now I’ve found his phone unlocked—she has his number saved as her best friend. I can’t take this anymore. I wish he would leave me. This isn’t fair.

Triggering Event: A customer, irritated by a long wait for assistance, snaps, "You old fogies are all the same, can't keep up!" The words echo through the quiet store as the woman, her face flushing deep crimson, feels a surge of anger. She clenches her fists, knuckles turning white, and takes a step towards the customer before pausing, her breath ragged.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god she is literally saying you're all the same, that's so rude why would anyone say something like that? Like I'm just standing there, listening to this whole rant while trying to help people and now you're attacking me? That's so uncalled for. You're always complaining about how we don't know what we're doing, but then you go off on someone and it's completely unfair. Why did she have to be so dramatic? It really makes no sense, especially considering the circumstances. I guess she felt threatened because she was already frustrated with us and didn't want to wait anymore. But come on, that wasn't necessary. There was no reason to snap like that. We're here to help people, not to provoke them.

Triggering Event: A lifelong recipe book, her treasured companion since childhood, was quietly tucked away by her husband while she slept, concerned it had become an unhealthy obsession. She discovered its absence days later, her heart pounding with rejection as she searched empty-handed through their home.
Generated Assessment: You have been told by a fortune teller that you are going to lose your beloved recipe book. The fortune teller predicts that this loss is inevitable and irreversible, and that you will never recover from it. They claim that you are being manipulated into thinking otherwise, but they assure you that the outcome is already set in stone. According to the fortune teller, you are becoming increasingly dependent on the recipe book, which has been your constant companion for years. This dependence is leading to a decline in your mental health, causing anxiety and depression. The fortune teller warns that you will soon realize the true value of the recipe book, and that you will be forced to let go of it forever. Despite this warning, you continue to cling to the recipe book, hoping against hope that it will somehow return. However, the fortune teller's prediction remains unshakeable, and you are left feeling hopeless and defeated. It appears that the fortune teller's words have struck a chord within you, and you begin to question your own sanity. You start to wonder if perhaps the recipe book holds more significance than you initially thought, and whether there might be a way to salvage what's left of your relationship with it. However, the fortune teller's message remains clear: the recipe book is gone, and nothing can change its fate. As you struggle to come to terms with this reality, you cannot help but feel a sense of despair wash over you. It seems as though the world has turned

Triggering Event: A parent approaches him after class, "Mr., I heard my child's been struggling with algebra. You promised extra help, but they said you've been canceling sessions."
Generated Assessment: Mr. Smith, I don't know what you're talking about. I'm the teacher who has nothing to do with this student's math problems. This is ridiculous. If your child was doing well, there would be no problem, right? Why are you bringing it up now? It's so unfair that you're trying to make me look bad like this. I didn't promise anything to this student, let alone an entire class. You're just trying to make me look terrible in front of everyone. What exactly did your child tell you about our sessions? Did they say something specific? Because if they did, then maybe I should have taken it more seriously before now. But honestly, I think you're overreacting here. This isn't fair, especially since we haven't even discussed this yet. It feels like you're trying to get under my skin. You need to focus on your own behavior rather than accusing me of things I never said. Let's focus on your students' grades instead of mine. Maybe you should check how many times you've canceled classes recently because it sounds like you might be the one who needs to work on your communication skills. But if you're going to bring this up, at least try to be constructive. Instead of attacking me, suggest ways I could improve my teaching methods. That way, we can have a productive conversation about this issue. Otherwise, I'll just ignore you and keep doing what I'm already doing. Let's talk about your

Triggering Event: "At 10 PM, she receives an email from her team lead marked 'Urgent'. It's a task she thought was completed weeks ago. She feels a wave of nausea as she reads it, alone in their shared apartment while he's out with friends."
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm such a fucking idiot. I can't believe I let this happen again. I feel like such a loser for letting that email slide into my inbox. Every time something like this happens, I just get so sick to my stomach. I hate being like this. I hate being me. It's always the same thing—overlooking tasks, then feeling guilty about it later. But why does it keep happening? Why do I always let things slip through the cracks? What is wrong with me? I'm just so stupid. I know I'm not supposed to check work emails at night, but damn, I got caught up in that video game and forgot all about it. Now I've got to deal with the consequences. My brain is a mess, and I don't even know how to fix it. This isn’t the first time I’ve messed up like this, and I’m starting to lose hope. I know I need to change, but what if I really am broken? Is it possible to actually be this bad? Maybe I’m just not meant to be responsible. Does that sound ridiculous? Of course not—it’s true! I mean, look at all these fuckups. If this keeps happening, maybe I really am a failure, and there's nothing I can do about it. I wish someone would tell me exactly what's wrong with me so I could stop feeling like shit. Maybe then I'd finally understand. But no, I'll just

Triggering Event: He returned home to find the kitchen empty, save for his wife's favorite mug still sitting beside the coffeemaker, untouched since her passing three months ago.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, he’s such an asshole! I mean, what does it even matter if he leaves his fucking coffee mug out? It’s not like she’ll be back from the afterlife anytime soon. And why is he even bothering with the whole grieving thing? She’s dead, so just leave her alone and move on already! If you’re going to sit there crying all day, at least have the decency to leave your stupid cup out so no one else feels sorry for you. What kind of sick fuck doesn’t clean up after themselves when they know someone can see it? He’s such a loser; he’s always leaving his shit everywhere, like he thinks he owns this house. Newsflash, buddy: she didn’t die because she was tired of cleaning up after you. If she had that problem, she would’ve left him years ago. Instead, she stayed with him because she loved him—something he clearly doesn’t deserve. If he wants to keep mourning over her death, fine. But he needs to stop making everyone around him feel uncomfortable by constantly bringing her up. We get it; she died. It’s been months now. Time to start living again. You need to pick yourself up and get back to work. The world isn’t going to wait for you while you wallow in sadness. And another thing: why is he still wearing those stupid funeral clothes? Doesn’t he realize how pathetic he looks? Those black pants and dark shirts are a constant reminder

Triggering Event: He missed his morning coffee, again. The automated machine at work had been acting up, spilling grounds everywhere. Now, it was refusing to brew his beloved dark roast. As he tried to fix it, a colleague walked by, laughing, "Still haven't mastered that thing, huh?" His fingers tightened around the scoop, irritation prickling his skin like static.
Generated Assessment: He missed his morning coffee, again. That guy must be a fucking idiot. I bet he can't even operate this stupid machine. I swear, he's always late with his coffee too. It's just another one of those things he does to slow me down. I'll show him how it's done when I get my damn coffee.
